intro: Abelia serrata var. glaberrima, commonly known as the smoothleaf abelia, is a deciduous shrub native to China. It features small, fragrant, white to pinkish flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The leaves are typically ovate to elliptical in shape and have a smooth, glabrous surface, giving the plant its varietal name. It thrives in partial shade to full sun and prefers well-drained, moist soil. This plant is often used in gardens for its ornamental value and hardy nature.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abelia serrata var. glaberrima is primarily native to Southeast Asia, including countries such as Thailand, Vietnam, and Cambodia. This variant is commonly found in lowland tropical forests and along riverbanks. It thrives in humid, warm climates with well-drained soil. The plant is often associated with secondary growth areas and can be found in both natural and cultivated settings. Its distribution is largely confined to the eastern regions of the Indochina Peninsula.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abelia serrata var. glaberrima was mainly introduced to the United States as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and flowers. It is commonly found in gardens and landscapes in the southeastern region of the country. This variety is known for its compact growth habit and ability to thrive in partial shade. It has been widely cultivated for its aesthetic value and adaptability to various soil conditions. However, it is important to note that it may pose a risk of becoming invasive in certain environments.
